body:
Data is a valuable resource to organisations of all sizes.

Increasing numbers of organisations are using data to grow their businesses, improve their operations and enhance services for their customers.

In this module we’ll explore the following:

  • What is data?
  • The data spectrum
  • Types of data
  • Why do we need data?
title: Overview

body:
Data is a valuable resource to organisations of all sizes. When used effectively, data can lead to new insights and unexpected benefits. Whether looking at operations, finance or products and services, organisations increasingly use data to understand how their business works and how they perform.

Without data we can’t build information, and without information there is no new knowledge.

Find out more about the diverse benefits of data-driven decisions in Unlocking value from open data and Convincing your colleagues.
title: Why do we need data?

_items.text: data that could influence the London markets
data that anyone can access, use and share
data that defines values to be used by other data

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Market sensitive data is data that could influence the London market or data that is proprietary to Lloyd’s.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Market sensitive data is data that could influence the London market or data that is proprietary to Lloyd’s.

body:
Data is the raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

Without data we can’t build information, and without information there is no new knowledge.

Data is a valuable resource to organisations of all sizes.  Increasing numbers of organisations are using data to grow their businesses, improve their operations and enhance services for their customers.

In the next module, we will explore how value is unlocked in open data.

title: Summary
Q: Why do we need data?

_items.text: understand how their business works and how they perform
Unlock social, environmental and economic value

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Whether looking at operations, finance or products and services, organisations increasingly use data to understand how their business works and how they perform.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Whether looking at operations, finance or products and services, organisations increasingly use data to understand how their business works and how they perform.

body: Without data we can’t build information, and without information there is no new knowledge.
title: What is data?
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Data
_items.body:
Data is the raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

Think of data as those locations, images, descriptions, reviews and prices that form the basis of information that can help you plan a holiday, for example.

_items.title: Information
_items.body:
Data becomes information when it is given a context.

Following on from the previous example, locations, images, descriptions and prices can all help provide information related to a tourist attraction.

The collection and presentation of data helps to form information.

_items.title: Knowledge
_items.body:
Knowledge is what is derived from information, and personalised for your needs.

Building knowledge is a process of turning information into choices.

Building on the previous example, knowing that no one in your family likes theme parks will help you to decide which places to avoid on holiday, and which would suit your family better.

_items.text: the raw material of information and knowledge.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Data is the lowest level of raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Data is the lowest level of raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

body: Group-based access data is data that is...
title: Q: The data spectrum

_items.text: shared with anyone who meets certain professional or usage conditions
free of restrictions for its use

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Group-based access data is shared with anyone who meets certain professional or usage conditions.

Group-based access is granted on the basis of authentication. The person accessing the data must prove, to the satisfaction of the sharing organisation, that they belong to the class of people granted access.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Group-based access data is shared with anyone who meets certain professional or usage conditions.

Group-based access is granted on the basis of authentication. The person accessing the data must prove, to the satisfaction of the sharing organisation, that they belong to the class of people granted access.

body:
Data exists on a spectrum, from closed to shared to open.

The data spectrum can help you classify and agree on sharing arrangements for your data assets. Click on each of the pins below to discover which data goes under which part of the spectrum.
title: The data spectrum

_items.title: Internal Access
_items.body:
Internal access is the most private type of data shared only with selected individuals inside the organisation.

Whether closed to protect sensitive personal information such as salaries or to keep private commercially sensitive details of operations, internal access data can only be accessed by those in specific roles within the organisation.

_items.title: Named access
_items.body:
Named access data is shared only with named individuals. These people can be inside the organisation or in partner organisations.

Named access data is only accessed on the based of a signed agreement between the party sharing the data and the party accessing it.

_items.title: Group-based access
_items.body:
Group-based access data is shared with anyone who meets certain professional or usage conditions. For example, you might choose to share product availability quantities with anyone working for a retailer but not with those working for a competitor.

Group-based access is granted on the basis of authentication. The person accessing the data must prove, to the satisfaction of the sharing organisation, that they belong to the class of people granted access.

_items.title: Public access
_items.body:
Public access data can be located online by anyone. However, while people may be able to find this data, there are still legal protections in place that prevent the free use or sharing of this data.

Your public access data is often part of your web presence or data you otherwise want people to experience without having the legal right to use and share that data themselves.

_items.title: Open
_items.body:
Open data is data that anyone can access use and share. Your open data is data that is accessible without limitation to the public subject to certain licence conditions such as the obligation to credit you as the source. 

Open data can be any non-personal data type where the organisation deems it more beneficial to share without restriction.

body: There are different types of data that you may come across. Below we explore some of the most common types of data at Lloyd's and where they fit on the data spectrum.
title: Types of data
instruction: Click the headings to explore further.

_items.title: Market data
_items.body:
Market data is data about the London market, provided by the London market, and available to those within the market, for example [the Lloyd’s statistics].

This is an example of shared data as it is group-based access.

_items.title: Market sensitive data
_items.body:
Market sensitive data is data that could influence the London market or data that is proprietary to Lloyd’s.

This is another example of shared data, but on internal or named based access.

_items.title: Reference data
_items.body:
Reference data is data that defines values to be used by other data.

Reference data becomes the most valuable when combined with other datasets.

Reference data can be open, shared, or closed. For example a dataset of country codes is open data. However, a reference dataset of risk codes or product IDs might be shared, either within an organisation (internal access) or between organisations (group-based access).

_items.title: Data exhaust
_items.body:
Data exhaust is data that is produced as a product of other data.

For example, on a telephone call the main data the voices and what is said. The data that is also produced is data like the location of the speakers, the length of time for the call and the phone operators involved.

Where data exhaust exists on the spectrum depends on the data. In the above example, it is likely to be shared on a group-based access. This will depend on the terms and conditions of the phone operators.

_items.title: Open data
_items.body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data becomes usable when made available in a common, machine-readable format.

Open data must be licensed. Its licence must permit people to use the data in any way they want, including transforming, combining and sharing it with others, even commercially.
